LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Kingdom of Cambodia 
 
Two  loans  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  Special 
Funds  resources  are  proposed  to  support  the  Second  Education 
Sector  Development  Program  (ESDP  II):  (i)  a  program  loan  for 
$20  million  equivalent;  and  (ii)  a  project  loan  for  $25  million 
equivalent to provide improved access to and quality of secondary 
education  in  the  poorest  40%  of  communes  in  Cambodia,  and 
lifelong  learning  opportunities  for  out-of-school  youth.  Technical 
assistance  for  education  regulatory  reform  and  governance  for 
decentralization in the amount of $500,000 is also proposed.  
 
The  purpose  of  ESDP  II  will  be  to  consolidate  current  initiatives 
and  extend  them  through  new  poverty-targeted  strategies  and 
broader coverage, building on the achievements of the Education 
Sector  Development  Program  (ESDP)  and  consistent  with  the 
Government’s  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (NPRS), 
2003–2005, and the Education Strategic Plan (ESP), 2004–2008. 
ESDP  II  will  also  support  the  National  Education  for  All  Plan 
2003–2015  in  line  with  the  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs).  Cambodia’s  NPRS  and  Second  Socio-Economic 
Development  Plan  highlight  education  development  as  central  to 
poverty reduction and socioeconomic development.

Sector  Description and Performance  

4. 
The high dependence of the workforce on low-productivity agriculture limits opportunities 
to escape from poverty and is a major constraint on poverty reduction. Currently, 35–40% of the 
population has expenditures below the poverty line, with 15–20% living in extreme poverty. The 
percentage  of  the  population  below  the  poverty  line  is  lowest  in  Phnom  Penh  (10–15%)  and 
highest in rural areas (40–45%). Around 80% of the poor live in the plains and Tonle Sap basin. 
Poverty is most severe in urban areas and the rural plateau and mountain zone, although these 
areas have relatively low incidence of poverty, indicating high levels of inequality. Almost 90% of 
the  poor  are  rural.  Incidence  of  higher  levels  of  poverty  correlates  strongly  with  levels  of 
participation  in  education  and  training  and  geographical  variations  in  provision  of  basic 
education  and  skills  training.  While  households  headed  by  women  are  not  significantly  poorer 
than others, they are often more vulnerable. Women, who are the primary promoters of school 
attendance, are particularly vulnerable. They have less land and access to labor, and thus rely

Issues and Opportunities  

5. 
Cambodia’s NPRS and Second Socio-Economic Development Plan highlight education 
development as central to poverty reduction and socioeconomic development. The revised ESP 
goes  further  by  establishing  the  necessary  human  resources  and  infrastructure  for  sector 
development  in  the  face  of  key  constraints,  such  as  the  shallow  human  resource  base  from 
which to draw people to take on education sector tasks and the very limited training resources 
for  the  large  number  of  unemployed  and  undereducated  youth.  These  constraints  have  to  be 
met,  while  uncertainties  in  labor  demand  are  prevalent  as  Cambodia  adjusts  to  economic 
trends, including those arising from its recent entry into the World Trade Organization.  
 
6. 
Demographic  and  labor  force  trends  will  increase  demand  for  education  and  training. 
The  labor  force  is  estimated  to  be  6.4  million,  or  49%  of  the  total  population.2  As  Cambodia’s 
population  is  relatively  young,  with  more  than  half  the  population  under  20  years  of  age,  it  is 
projected  that  150,000  to  175,000  people  will  join  the  labor  force  every  year.  High  levels  of 
economic  growth  will  be  needed  to  translate  this  into  job  creation.  The  comparatively  low 
education level of the workforce, with 75% having primary education or lower and less than 3% 
having upper secondary, diploma or graduate qualifications, is recognized as a major constraint 
on Cambodia’s economic competitiveness and labor productivity. An education sector analysis 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
Provision of education and training opportunities is a joint task of the general education 
7. 
system  and  the  technical  and  vocational  education  and  training  (TVET)  system.  However, 
among youth 15 years and over, the reach of the general education system, and of the upper 
secondary  schools  in  particular,  is  limited  because  the  great  majority  of  youth  drop  out  early. 
Based on school year 2002–2003 data, out of a cohort of 100 pupils entering grade 1, only 15 
will reach grade 12, of whom only 7 will pass the examination and be eligible to pursue higher 
education.  This  puts  the  burden  primarily  on  the  TVET  system.  The  current  TVET  delivery 
system  has  limited  capacity,  as  it  is  largely  supply-driven,  located  mainly  in  urban  areas, 
fragmented, and in need of significant quality improvement.  
 
8. 
The  Government  recognizes  the  urgency  of  action  to  expand  education  and  training

11.

supplies and teaching materials and for carrying out improvements to the school environment. 
Grant allocation formulas are specifically designed to be pro-poor, through higher allocations to 
smaller schools frequently located in the poorest communes.

Objectives 

The program loan will support policy interventions aimed at (i) improving equity in access

to  education  and  training  services  through  pro-poor  systemic  and  targeted  interventions; 
(ii) improving  quality  and  internal  efficiency  through  more  effective  curriculum  organization, 
improved student progression, enhancing the teaching and learning environment, and improved 
standard  monitoring  and  quality  assurance;  (iii)  enhancing  capacity  for  greater  education 
decentralization  through  strengthened  financial  planning,  management  and  audit  systems,  a 
more  focused  human  resource  planning  system,  and  more  efficient  staff  performance 
management, deployment and reward systems; and (iv) increasing resource mobilization linked 
to measures that ensure resource allocation is pro-poor, equitable and efficient.   
 
39. 
Since the adoption of ESP and ESSP in 2001, the Government has realized some major 
achievements in education sector reform, facilitated by extensive policy and strategic dialogue 
with  ADB  technical  assistance  and  advisory  support  from  UNICEF  and  the  Swedish 
International Development Agency (Sida), the World Bank, the European Commission and the 
NGO community. The next phase of ESP reform, from 2004 to 2008, is designed to deepen and 
extend  the  reform  program  with  a  view  to  achieving  (i)  further  reductions  in  cost  barriers  for 
basic  education  access,  alongside  the  extension  of  well-regulated  and  managed  parental 
contributions  in  post-basic  education;  (ii)  expansion  of  secondary  education  opportunities, 
especially in poorer and underserved rural communes; (iii) a more demand-driven approach to 
expanded  skills  training  opportunities,  especially  in  the  poorest  40%  of  communes  which  are 
severely  underserved;  (iv)  improved  quality  and  standards  in  schools  by  strengthening 
education  governance  mechanisms  and  accountability  at  the  school-community  interface;  and 
(v) greater delegated authority to provinces, districts and schools for planning and management 
of resources, alongside extensive capacity building in financial management and audit.  
 
40. 
Faced  with  prospective  budget  constraints,  the  Government  recognizes  that  financial 
sustainability  will  require  not  only  additional  resource  mobilization,  but  also  gains  in  efficiency 
and  other  forms  of  cost  containment.  The  key  feature  of  this  phase  of  reform  will  be  to 
implement systemic efficiency gains (e.g., reduce repetition and make more efficient use of staff 
and  facilities)  so  that  additional  resources  can  be  directed  towards  service  expansion.  This 
phase  also  recognizes  that  directing  more  resources  to  quality-oriented  activities  will  not  be 
enough  to  improve  standards.  Accordingly,  greater  emphasis  will  be  given  to  target  setting, 
standard setting and student performance monitoring systems. A critical cross-cutting reform will 
be  to  adjust  the  salary  and  nonsalary  shares  of  education  expenditure  through  gradual 
improvements  in  performance-based  teacher  allowances,  building  on  the  initial  program 
introduced  in  2002.  Increased  teacher  remuneration  is  also  designed  to  reduce  demands  for 
informal  payments  from  parents  (a  major  access  barrier)  and  promote  increased  community 
oversight and accountability of school performance.

The  initial  phase  of  ESP  and  ESSP  implementation  benefited  from  high-level  political 
support,  strong  strategic  leadership,  and  significant  increases  in  Government  resources  for

resistance  from  a  range  of  education  stakeholders.  ESDP  II  is  designed  to  meet  part  of  the 
adjustment  costs  and  to  contain  pressure  on  public  resources.  The  proposed  phasing  and 
sequencing  of  the  reforms,  particularly  undertaking  initial  capacity  building  before  nationwide 
implementation,  is  designed  to  mobilize  support  and  ensure  that  the  reform  strategies  are 
technically sound.

Objectives 

52. 
The objectives of the Project are to supplement the policy initiatives under the Program 
and to enhance equitable access, improve the quality of lower and upper secondary education, 
and provide demand driven, community-based skills training opportunities mainly for the out-of-
school  youth,  in  underserved  areas,  through  (i)  lower  secondary  education  opportunities,  (ii)

schools,  provide  schools  in  districts  where  there  are  none,  and  rehabilitate  existing  upper 
secondary  schools  where  needed,  (iii)  enhance  capacity  of  national  and  provincial  training 
boards  to  facilitate  skills  training  in  the  poorest  communes,  (iv)  introduce  a  sustainable  skills 
training voucher system, and (v) strengthen standards monitoring at upper secondary and TVET 
and skills training levels. Core ESP performance indicators are in supplementary Appendix G.

a. 

Expanding Lower Secondary Education Opportunities 

53. 
The  MOEYS  target  is  to  increase  enrollment  to  around  1  million  in  lower  secondary 
education over the next 5 to 7 years. Currently, it is estimated that there are between 800 and 
900  communes  that  do  not  have  a  lower  secondary  school.  The  lack  of  immediate  access  to 
lower  secondary  schooling  in  these  communes  contributes  to  low  progression  and  transition 
rates from commune-based primary schools.  
 
54.

underserved communes through: (i) provision of around 400 lower secondary school buildings 
in  selected  high-demand  communes,  and  (ii)  staff  development  (training  of  central,  provincial 
and  district  education  staff  for  decentralized  delivery  of  education;  planning,  financial 
management,  monitoring;  district  and  community  level  program  implementation).  To  support 
(i) and  (ii),  the  Project  will  provide  equipment,  furniture,  instructional  materials,  computers, 
training, consulting services, civil works, utility vehicles and motorcycles. Detailed geographical 
and  other  targeting  criteria  will  be  based  on  a  basic  education  facilities  development  plan

91. 
The  policy  reforms  supported  by  the  ESDP  II  program  loan  will  generate  medium-term 
benefits by improving equity and efficiency by redistributing education resources provided by the 
Government and development agencies, including financial, human and physical infrastructure, 
to the poorest 40% of communes in Cambodia.  Preliminary analysis indicates that over the five 
years  of  the  ESP  implementation  (2004–2008),  which  ESDP  II  will  enable,  the  share  of 
projected spending in the poorest 40% of communes will rise from 28% to 36%, compared with 
a decrease in the share spent on the richest 40% of communes from 50% to 42%. Similarly, the 
projected  spending  on  girls  will  increase  from  42%  of  projected  total  capital  and  recurrent 
spending in 2004 to 46% of spending by 2008, through systemic and targeted support in areas 
of low female enrolment and participation. An economic and financial analysis of ESDP II is in 
Appendix J.   
 
92. 
The  medium-term  benefits  of  the  ESP  2004–2008  reforms,  which  ESDP  II  and  other 
donor  assistance  will  enable,  will  be:  (i)  increased  participation  in  basic  education  for  an 
estimated  0.8  million  students  in  the  poorest  40%  of  communes;  (ii)  increased  participation  in 
upper secondary education for around 0.2 million students; (iii) enabling an additional 0.6 million 
children  to progress  annually  to  the  next  grade  of  school,  with  savings  of  around  KR24  billion 
($6 million) to the Government and KR6 billion ($1.5 million) to parents; and (iv) expanded skills 
training opportunities for over 270,000 youths and adults in the poorest 40% of communes over 
5  years  during  the  initial  phase  of  this  project  component.  The  longer-term  benefits  will  be  to 
provide more accessible and relevant formal education to about 4.2 million school-age children

Since  2001,  MOEYS  has  taken  steps  to  reduce  repetition  rates  in  primary  schools 
through  remedial  programs  during  vacations.  This  has  resulted  in  an  improvement  in  student 
progression  rates  across  the  primary  grades.  Nevertheless,  repetition  rates  remained  high, 
resulting in significant costs for the Government and poor families.  For grade 1, the promotion

above anticipated levels, particularly in grades 1 and 2. However, over the full grade 1–6 range,

the  poorest  families.  This  is  exacerbated  by  the  existence  of  incomplete  primary  schools, 
frequently  located  in  the  poorest  communes.  Two  strategic  priorities  are  (i)  to  introduce  cost-
effective remedial programs alongside monitoring of primary grade standards, and (ii) to phase 
out  incomplete  primary  schools  by  making  better  use  of  staff  and  facilities  and  selectively 
expanding the number of classrooms.
